instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-01987: What is 820-01987? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PP3V3_G3H: What is PP3V3_G3H? PP3V3_G3H is a 3.3v power line that is present when the machine is in a Global System Hardware Off state, and should come on before most other rails so that the USB-C circuitry can be powered for the charger.
definitions.PP5V_G3S: What is PP5V_G3S? PP5V_G3S is a 5v power rail present when the system is in a G3S standby state.
definitions.PP3V3_G3S: What is PP3V3_G3S? PP3V3_G3S is a 3.3v power rail present when the machine is in a G3S standby state. .
definitions.PP1V8_S3: What is PP1V8_S3? The PP1V8_S3 signal in the MacBook schematic is a power rail that provides a voltage of 1.8 volts during the S3 power state. The S3 state, often referred to as "suspend to RAM," is a low-power mode where the computer saves the session's state to RAM, allowing for quicker wake-up times compared to a full shutdown..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01987</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 20V no current
threads.message:
Board draws 20V  0.00A
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>=12.60V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>/rtc=3.309v
<SIGNAL>PP5V_G3S</SIGNAL>=5.1v
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3S</SIGNAL>=3.3v
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL>=3.3
<SIGNAL>PP5V_G3H_LDO</SIGNAL>=5.1v
I have tried dfu... completed and shows padlock on the host screen but no display

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01987</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 20V no current
threads.message:
Any history available?
Did you check for voltage on other big coils?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01987</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 20V no current
threads.message: No voltages on any coils except L7030=8.2V

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01987</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 20V no current
threads.message:
Did you try with both charger and battery connected?
Does it charge the battery?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01987</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 20V no current
threads.message: Yes it charge the battery it draws 2.13A when battery is connected

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01987</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 20V no current
threads.message:
Check diode mode to ground on all coils.
Compare with good board.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01987</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 20V no current
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01987</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 20V no current
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01987</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 20V no current
threads.message:
Trigger <SIGNAL>PMU_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> and check for pulse at <CHIP>U8100</CHIP>, pins 16 &17; you can use SE030/31 pads.

You should also test the board alone on the desk.
